facts.text: Bye-election to the Lok Sabha from Darbhanga Parliamentary Constituency held on January 30, 1972.
Respondent Lalit Narain Mishra (Indian National Congress candidate) declared elected on February 2, 1972, by a margin of 91,078 votes against Ramsewak Yadava (Socialist Party candidate).
Appellant, an elector in the constituency, presented election petition on Monday, March 20, 1972, instead of Saturday, March 18, 1972, which was the last day of 45-day limitation under s.81 RPA 1951.
Patna High Court dismissed the election petition as time-barred by judgment and order dated March 26, 1973.
Appeal filed under s.116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Patna High Court has Rules for Disposal of Election Petitions, including R.6 and R.7 requiring presentation to Stamp Reporter first, then formal presentation to Judge or Bench in open Court.
Judges of Patna High Court do not sit on Saturdays, but court office is open.
R.26 of Patna High Court Rules allows presentation to Registrar etc. on days no Bench sits, to be presented to Bench next day.

legal_issues.text: Is the Court closed on Saturday, when the Judges do not sit, for the purposes either of s.10 of the General Clauses Act, or s.4 of the Limitation Act?
By virtue of s.29(2) of the Limitation Act, are the provisions of ss.4 to 24 of the said Act applicable to election petitions?
If they are, and s.5 of the Limitation Act is applicable, do the facts of the case warrant condonation of delay?

petitioner_arguments.text: Election petition should only be filed before a Judge sitting in open Court per R.6 and R.7 of Patna High Court Rules for Disposal of Election Petitions; since Judges do not sit on Saturday, court closed, filing on next Monday March 20, 1972 in time under s.4 Limitation Act or s.10 General Clauses Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: R.6 and R.7 Patna High Court Election Rules; s.4 Limitation Act 1963; s.10 General Clauses Act 1897

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if beyond time, s.5 Limitation Act 1963 applies via s.29(2), and sufficient cause shown for condonation.

respondent_arguments.text: Court not closed on Saturday as office open; long course of decisions hold court not closed if open otherwise even if Judges do not sit; R.6 and R.7 to be read with R.26 Patna High Court Rules allowing filing with Registrar on no-sit days.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Patna High Court Rules R.26; precedents like Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Girdhari Lal

respondent_arguments.text: s.5 Limitation Act does not apply to election petitions as RPA 1951 is complete code; s.86 mandates dismissal if s.81 not complied with.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.29(2) Limitation Act; s.81, s.86 RPA 1951; precedents like K. Venkateswara Rao v. Bekkam Narasimha Reddi

court_reasoning.text: Court not closed on Saturday when Judges do not sit but office open; precedents hold court open for filing if office open; R.6,7 Election Rules read with R.26 High Court Rules allow presentation to Registrar on such days.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Saturday is a court day though Judges not sitting; petition could have been presented to Registrar on March 18, 1972.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Limitation Act applies via s.29(2), RPA 1951 is complete self-contained code; scheme and nature exclude ss.4-24; s.86 peremptorily mandates dismissal for non-compliance with s.81; no express exclusion needed as intent clear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions like s.86, absence of condonation clause unlike repealed s.85, indicate legislative intent against application of Limitation Act provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to consider condonation under s.5 as not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: RPA provides expeditious disposal; no power to condone delay in filing election petition.

holdings.text: Court is not closed on Saturday for purposes of filing election petition; could be filed with Registrar per rules.
Provisions of s.5 Limitation Act do not apply to election petitions under s.81 RPA 1951 as Act is complete code excluding them.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.H. Raja Harinder Singh v. Karnail Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: s.10 General Clauses Act applies to election petitions filed later than period if court closed on last day.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Girdhari Lal Chaudhuri
precedents_cited.relevance: Saturday is court day though Judges not sitting.
Court offices open for presentation even if Judges not sitting.
Court open on Saturday for receiving papers though judicial work starts Monday.
s.29(2) Limitation Act (old) applies to appeals under RPA s.116A.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. Venkateswara Rao v. Bekkam Narasimha Reddi
precedents_cited.relevance: Limitation Act provisions like s.5 not applicable to election petitions; RPA complete code.
RPA complete code for election disputes.
s.12 Limitation Act applies to CrPC s.417 appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes 45-day limit for election petitions; mandates dismissal if not complied with; complete code for election disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: ss.4-24 not applicable to election petitions under RPA as expressly excluded by scheme.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies if court closed on last day, but court not closed on Saturday.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Patna High Court order dismissing election petition as time-barred; held court not closed on Saturday and s.5 Limitation Act inapplicable.

key_quotes.text: There is no doubt that election petition in this case has been presented beyond the period of 45 days and has necessarily to be dismissed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges petition late but examines exceptions.

key_quotes.text: The Representation of the People Act is a complete and self-contained code which does not admit of the introduction of the principles or the provisions of law contained in the Indian Limitation Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on inapplicability of Limitation Act.

key_quotes.text: The legislature in its wisdom has made the observance of certain formalities and provisions obligatory and failure in that respect can only be visited with a dismissal of the petition.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes mandatory nature of s.81 RPA.
